info.headline: Air Quality Alert issued May 28 at 3:01PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ...AIR QUALITY ALERT... The following message is transmitted at the request of the New Mexico Departments of Health and Environment, United States Forest Service and the Interagency Wildland Fire Air Quality Response Program. * WHAT...Smoke from the largest fires in the state will be rapidly transported toward the northeast through the remainder of the afternoon and evening. The most impactful near-surface smoke will remain in close proximity to the fire`s perimeters, particularly portions of the Mimbres and Lower Rio Grande valleys in southwest New Mexico. Additionally, layers of dense smoke aloft will be carried much farther downwind than recent days. This includes areas between Belen and Socorro northeast toward Abo Pass, Mountainair, Estancia, Moriarty, and Clines Corners along I-40. Smoke along the east slopes of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains will also push farther northeast resulting in diminished air quality for parts of the I-25 corridor in northeast New Mexico and surrounding areas. Overall, haze will be more persistent away from the larger fires and areas of blowing dust will, at times, contribute to diminished air quality for lower elevations through the evening. * WHERE...The most significant impacts from smoke are expected to persist across much of Catron, Socorro, northern Grant, northwest Lincoln, northern Luna, Sierra counties, and southwest Torrance counties in central and southwest New Mexico and western San Miguel, western Mora and western Colfax counties in north-central New Mexico. More details on impacted locations and latest air quality information can be found at https://fire.airnow.gov. * WHEN...Remainder of this afternoon through at least 1 pm MDT, Sunday, May 29, 2022. * IMPACTS...Those with conditions such as asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, interstitial lung disease, lung cancer, and heart disease will be especially vulnerable to impacts from poor air quality, as will adults over age 65, young children, and pregnant women if smoke concentrations become unhealthy. * HEALTH INFORMATION...Remember, your eyes are your best tools to determine if it is safe to be outside. Use the 5-3-1 Method available at https://nmtracking.doh.nm.gov/environment/air/FireAndSmoke.html. If visibility is: Under 5 miles, the air quality is unhealthy for young children, adults over age 65, pregnant women, and people with heart and/or lung disease, asthma or other respiratory illness. Outdoor activity should be minimized. Around 3 miles, young children, adults over age 65, pregnant women, and people with heart and/or lung disease, asthma or other respiratory illness should avoid all outdoor activities. Around 1 mile, the air quality is unhealthy for everyone. People should remain indoors and avoid all outdoor activities including running errands. Unless an evacuation has been issued, stay inside your home, indoor workplace, or in a safe shelter. With the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic affecting New Mexico and with the wildfire season underway, New Mexicans will need to take extra precautions. Smoke from wildfires may cause people to have more severe reactions if they are infected COVID-19. The best way to protect against the potentially harmful effects of wildfire smoke and to reduce the spread of COVID-19 is to stay home and create a clean indoor air space. NMDOH offers tips here: https://nmtracking.doh.nm.gov/environment/air/IndoorQuality.html and https://cv.nmhealth.org New Mexicans will also need to take steps to keep their homes cool to avoid heat-related illnesses. NMDOH offers tips here: https://nmtracking.doh.nm.gov/health/climate/HeatIllness.html. For smoke forecast outlooks from the Interagency Wildland Fire Air Quality Response Program please visit: https://outlooks.wildlandfiresmoke.net.
